results.title: A Festival of nine lessons and carols; King's College Choir
results.brief_description: Filmed in the chapel of King’s College, Cambridge, the world famous King’s College Choir perform the traditional Christmas festival of nine lessons and carols. The carols include all of the standard favourites, such as “Once in Royal David’s city”, “O little town of Bethlehem”, “We three kings of orient are” and “O come all ye faithful”. The second half of the video is a documentary which shows the lives of the choristers and scholars in the school, some performances and their preparations for the Christmas festival as well as explaining the history of the school and the chapel. The Choir is directed by Stephen Cleobury.

results.title: A Feeling of self worth
results.brief_description: A feeling of self worth describes the approach taken at Monterey and the positive impact this has had on the school. Present and former staff and the parents of former students talk about the school as it used to be and the improvements that have been made

results.title: A Fatherless village = Mei you ba ba de cun zhuang
results.creator_credit: Children's Film Studio (China) and Lu Ping
results.brief_description:
“Disaster befalling mankind is everlasting. So is the love of human beings.”

The film focuses on the plight of orphaned children, in this case mostly from natural disasters, and the “SOS Villages”, founded in China to provide a more nurturing environment for the traumatised young survivors.

The film opens dramatically with an infant crying out for their mother, amid the destruction of a horrendous volcano eruption. This sets the scene for a collection of young boys and girls, who have been orphaned and sent to one of these “SOS villages”, modeled on the first post-World War II institutions founded by Austrian Doctor Germanile. The village is a collection of several households, with the half-dozen children in each being watched over by a single “auntie”.

The oldest and most rabid of these orphans is Pi Tao, who had to be forcibly separated from his only remaining companion, a mangy dog by the name of Huazi. He enjoys hunting birds (to eat) and is quick to brandish his knife. Living on the street has proven a hard life, and earlier abuse by his grandparents has taught him to assert himself by bullying others and attention win attention with violence. Pi Tao exerts a strong influence as an older role model over the younger children, who are not only young and impressionable but extremely sensitive. They often express this deep psychological trauma at nighttime, which therefore ends up being one of the more lively times of the day. The children suffer from terrifying nightmares, sleepwalk on the roof, and are prone to invite a variety of mischief that ends in the whole village being woken up.

Needless to say, the unrest precipitated by the mental scars of these kids takes a certain toll on their adoptive “aunties”, who through loyalty to their children are often forced to come to loggerheads with the other guardians in the village.

The three aunties featured in the film are neatly stereotyped as; Meng Qiaoling “the strong one”, Yang Qing “The inexperienced — but pretty — youthful one”, and Bai Jin “the homely old widowed one”. As the film progresses their own personal stories unfold, explaining not only their backgrounds and reasons for taking on this role, but also the social stigmas associated with single mothers, adoption, orphans and the lack of a support network for those in desperate need of loving care but are denied it.

The moral of the film, like most others of the period, is that human beings are inherently good, and should therefore be prepared to compromise with the shortcomings and difficulties in associating with others. However, it also touches a much deeper and more fundamental nerve that stretches across all barriers, that society can only function humanely if its people remember their own natural desire to love and be loved, despite the risks of pain engendered through such ventures. With that said, viewers should not expect to be thoroughly entertained, as the film is often rather tedious and dry.
(2 stars - James Donald; June 6, 2011)

results.title: A Faroe Islands family
results.creator_credit: Nordisk Films Kompagni and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Illustrates the geographical features of the Faroe Islands, showing how they affect the lives of the inhabitants, making farming difficult. Highland pastures afford grazing for large flocks of sheep and a few horses and cows. The wool is plucked by hand and carded, spun and woven in the farm houses. Extensive fishing operations are a mainstay of the economy of the islands.

results.title: A Farmer's boy
results.brief_description: Film about a farmer’s son who is about to start working on his father’s farm. The boy’s parents suggest that he goes to agricultural college. Shows the work of Seale-Hayne Agricultural College, Devon including students pig feeding, milking, butter making, poultry rearing, ploughing, machine maintenance and sheep shearing.

results.title: A Far off world
results.brief_description: A love story set on another planet. A girl finds herself in doubt about a relationship with her friend. She seeks advice from the Master of the Planet. He grants her wish but she finds later that it is not quite what she had in mind.

results.title: A Family talks about sex
results.creator_credit: Wexler Film Productions, E C Brown Foundation and Larry Yust
results.brief_description: Deals with situations parents face in giving their children guidance and information about sex. Emphasises that if the parent-child relationship is based on love, respect and trust, then there is reason to hope that the children will make responsible decisions about sex.

results.title: A Family of Tokyo
results.brief_description: A working day and a holiday in the life of a Japanese middle-class family of a husband, wife and three school-age children. Shows the respective status, roles and functions of family members and the ble.ding of the traditional and modern in family life

results.title: A Family group
results.creator_credit: FilmFair, Ivor Wood and Michael Bond
results.brief_description:
Animated children’s story about Paddington Bear and his adventures. In this chapter Paddington goes out and buys a camera so that he can take a photograph of the family.
Adapted from Chapter 1 from the book: More about paddington. Narrated by Michael Hordern.

results.title: A Family affair: conflict
results.creator_credit: Mental Health Film Board and Irving Jacoby
results.brief_description: An 18 year-old boy leaves home against his parents’ wishes to work in a summer theatre. This aggravates the tense family atmosphere which results from an over-anxious and over-possessive mother and a father who is frustrated and withdrawn into himself. They both agree to seek help from a social case-worker who helps them to continue marriage as responsible adults. When the teenage daughter wishes to go out with someone of whom mother does not approve, father is able to persuade mother that the girl should be allowed to make her own mistakes.
